title: Powell STOLport
text:
Powell STOLport was a privately owned, public use <a href="STOLport">STOLport</a> in <a href="Knox%20County%2C%20Tennessee">Knox County, Tennessee</a>, United States. It is located five <a href="nautical%20mile">nautical mile</a>s (9 <a href="kilometre">km</a>) northwest of the <a href="central%20business%20district">central business district</a> of <a href="Knoxville%2C%20Tennessee">Knoxville, Tennessee</a>. This facility had a runway designed for use by <a href="STOL">STOL</a> (short take-off and landing) aircraft.
The airport was <a href="Municipal%20annexation%20in%20the%20United%20States">annexed</a> by the City of Knoxville in April 2003.
The airport closed in the mid-2000s, and served its final flight in April 2012 when the then-owners sold the last aircraft that had been stored at the facility. It is scheduled to become a shopping center based around a <a href="Kroger">Kroger</a> store.
Facilities and aircraft.
Powell STOLport covered an area of 30 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (12 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 992 feet (302 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It had one <a href="runway">runway</a> designated 5/23 with an <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> surface measuring 2,600 by 50 feet (792 x 15 m).
For the 12-month period ending February 9, 2000, the airport had 1,375 <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> aircraft operations, an average of 26 per week. At that time there were 5 aircraft based at this airport: 80% single-<a href="aircraft%20engine">engine</a> and 20% multi-engine.
